items.author: Tom Huddleston
items.content: This is a story of identity, and the lack of it. And it’s fascinating.

items.author: Kevin Harley
items.content: Between the vast exteriors and candlelit interiors, the expressive authority of Kubrick’s direction is breathtaking.

items.author: John Bleasdale
items.content: Barry Lyndon is a rich cinematic experience which fully deserves to once more be seen on the big screen and enjoy its status as one of Stanley Kubrick’s greatest achievements.

items.author: Peter Bradshaw
items.content: Barry Lyndon is an intimate epic of utter lucidity and command.

items.author: Owen Gleiberman
items.content: To watch Ryan O’Neal’s performance as the upwardly mobile Barry, part victim and part cad, is to see Kubrick’s perverse genius with actors. He cast a dullard only to jolt us, by the end, with the revelation of the bastard within.

items.author: David Sims
items.content: It’s a movie that actually makes the past look otherworldly, unlike many period pieces, which strive to make history seem easy to slip into.

items.author: Vincent Canby
items.content: Barry Lyndon is another fascinating challenge from one of our most remarkable, independent-minded directors.

items.author: Josh Larsen
items.content: Barry Lyndon is a costume epic that pokes fun of other costume epics even as it outdoes them.

items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: Barry Lyndon isn’t a great success, and it’s not a great entertainment, but it’s a great example of directorial vision.

items.author: Ian Nathan
items.content: Kubrick's superb version of William Thackery's first novel is meticulous and philosophically stimulating but it can leave some audiences unmoved on an emotional level.
